_user_! You have helped ComputerStudent1 so much I can already tell.
Indeed ComputerTutor. Now I know how to cash my check, what bank I can cash it at,and how to pay my bill.
Try to remember the strategies we used in this lesson when you read from now on.
Sure ComputerTutor! _user_ now we know what makes a narrative, a persuasive, and an informational text different from each other.
Remember the article about cashing a check was an informational text, it provided you with facts such as how to endorse a check.
And the article about the woman paying her bill, that was a narrative because it contained emotion triggers.

The Williford bank ad was persuasive. The bank is trying to convince ComputerStudent1 that he should cash his check there. The bank uses opinions to convince. Remember that opinions are not facts, they can be argued against.
Well I should go cash my check now. Thanks again _user_! Bye ComputerTutor.
Goodbye ComputerStudent1 and _user_! You two have a great day and try to do another lesson soon!
Hi _user_ and ComputerStudent1! How are you two today!
Hey ComputerTutor and _user_! I have been better. I received a check from my new job but I don't have a checking account.
Don't worry ComputerStudent1, _user_ and I are here to help you. I found three different articles about cashing checks and paying bills that may help!
Cool Christina. What kind of articles?
I found a persuasive article, an informational article, and a narrative article.
Persuasive, informational and narrative articles. Got it.

Persuasive articles use opinions to try and convince the reader of some point of view. An informational article contains many facts and is meant to inform the reader. A narrative text tells a story and entertains us by affecting our emotions.
So I should pay attention to facts, opinions and emotion triggers when I read.
You got it! Let's take a look at the first article _user_.
Read the article below and then we will talk about it. Click the blue continue button when you are done reading. Remember to use the read text button if you need help.

Question.text: _user_, based on what we read, do you think this article is informational, persuasive, or narrative?

Answer.name: Correct
Answer.text: This is an informational text because the writer uses facts to inform us about how to cash a check.

Answer.name: IncorrectPrompt
Answer.text: Remember that facts, opinions, and emotion triggers inform us about the type of text. So does this text have a lot of facts, opinions or emotion triggers _user_? Think about it and then try a different answer choice.

Answer.name: BlankPrompt
Answer.text: It's not a problem if you need more time _user_. Remember to look for facts, opinions and emotion triggers.

Answer.name: Assertion
Answer.text: This is an informational text because the writer uses facts to to inform us about how to cash a check.

Answer.name: AskJordan
Answer.text: Do you know the answer ComputerStudent1?

Answer.name: JordanAnswer
Answer.text: Is it a persuasive article ComputerTutor? I'm not sure.

Question.text: So _user_, what could happen to you or ComputerStudent1 if you accept a check from someone you don't know?

Answer.name: Correct
Answer.text: If ComputerStudent1 accepts a check from someone he doesn't know the check could bounce.

Answer.name: IncorrectPrompt
Answer.text: _user_ in the first section it says you should trust the person who wrote the check. What else does it say can happen if you don't trust the check writer?

Answer.name: BlankPrompt
Answer.text: This one was tricky for me too _user_. It's ok if you don't know the answer, just pick the best choice you see.

Answer.name: Assertion
Answer.text: If you accept a check from a person who is not trustworthy, the check could bounce. Make sure you trust the person who writes you a check.

Answer.name: AskJordan
Answer.text: ComputerStudent1 which answer did you select?

Answer.name: JordanAnswer
Answer.text: Thanks _user_! I get it now! If I accept a check from someone I don't know I can receive fees and the check could bounce.

Question.text: _user_ why do I need my ID when I am getting a check cashed? I don't know why it's important.

Answer.name: Correct
Answer.text: The bank has to verify that Jordans ID matches the name on the check before they can cash it! You have selected the correct answer.

Answer.name: IncorrectPrompt
Answer.text: _user_ if ComputerStudent1 doesn't have his ID he can't cash his check, but why? Why does he need to have his ID when he goes to cash his check _user_?

Answer.name: BlankPrompt
Answer.text: _user_ did you need more time to answer the question? Why do I need my ID when I go cash my check?

Answer.name: Assertion
Answer.text: ComputerStudent1 has to bring his ID to the bank to prove to them he is who he says he is. The bank has to verify ComputerStudent1's identity before they can cash his check!

Answer.name: AskJordan
Answer.text: ComputerStudent1 what do you think the answer is to the question?

Answer.name: JordanAnswer
Answer.text: I see _user_! This is important. The bank requires my ID to verify that I am who I say I am.

Question.text: _user_, I have highlighted this sentence in the article for you! Does this sentence contain an opinion, a fact, or an emotion trigger?

Answer.name: Correct
Answer.text: A fact states something that cannot be denied. In this case the fact is, to endorse a check you always have to flip it over and sign next to the x. Great job recognizing this is a fact _user_!

Answer.name: IncorrectPrompt
Answer.text: _user_ this sentence contains a piece of information that can not be changed. This type of information can be found in informational texts. So _user_, does this sentence contain a fact, an opinion, or an emotion trigger?

Answer.name: BlankPrompt
Answer.text: _user_ did you need more time to answer the question? Try your best. Does this sentence contain a fact, an opinion, or an emotion trigger?

Answer.name: Assertion
Answer.text: This sentence contains a fact. The sentence states information that can not be argued against. The fact here was, In order to endorse a check you always have to flip it over and sign next to the x.

Answer.name: AskJordan
Answer.text: What do you think the answer is ComputerStudent1?

Answer.name: JordanAnswer
Answer.text: I'm not sure ComputerTutor, but I think it might be an emotion trigger.

Answer.name: BlankPrompt

Answer.name: Assertion

Answer.name: AskJordan

Answer.name: JordanAnswer
Answer.text: Welp... I think it might be a narrative ad, but I might be wrong.

Question.text: _user_ which of the highlighted phrases do you think is trying to convince ComputerStudent1?

Answer.name: Correct
Answer.text: The phrase "we have the most helpful tellers" is a convincing statement, and not a fact or emotion trigger. Great answer _user_!

Answer.name: IncorrectPrompt

Answer.name: BlankPrompt
Answer.text: _user_ the Williford bank claims to have the most helpful bank tellers. That is one reason they believe they are the number one bank! The ad is trying to convince us of that.

Answer.name: Assertion
Answer.text: The Williford bank claims to have the most helpful bank tellers. That is one reason why they think they are the number one bank in the country! The ad is trying to convince us of that.

Answer.name: AskJordan
Answer.text: What do you think the answer is ComputerStudent1?

Answer.name: JordanAnswer
Answer.text: I think the highlighted phrase check cashing is trying to convince me. But I could be wrong.

Question.text: Williford bank is trying to convince us that they are the number one bank in the country, right? How can we know if this is an opinion _user_?

Answer.name: Correct
Answer.text: Some people will think the opinion that they have the most helpful bank tellers is true, while others might not agree. An opinion is not a fact, which means it has not been proven. You picked the correct answer.

Answer.name: IncorrectPrompt
Answer.text: _user_ remember that an opinion is different from a fact because a fact is proven information. So how can we know that Williford banks claim is an opinion?

Answer.name: BlankPrompt
Answer.text: _user_ give it a shot. How can we know if the statement, Williford bank is the number one bank in the country, is an opinion?

Answer.name: Assertion
Answer.text: An opinion is something that can be argued. Some people will think it is true while others will think it is not true. Also, an opinion is not a fact, which means it has not shown to be true.

Answer.name: AskJordan
Answer.text: ComputerStudent1 what do you think the answer is?

Answer.name: JordanAnswer
Answer.text: _user_ I understand now! The statement is an opinion because it has not been proven. Nice!

Answer.name: IntroducePassage
Answer.text: This passage is about a woman who had a bad experience when paying a bill! I think you may find this interesting so take a look! _user_ remember to click the continue button at the bottom of the page once you have finished reading.

Question.text: _user_, do you think this text is informational, persuasive, or narrative?

Answer.name: Correct
Answer.text: The passage tells us a story of how Anne pays her bills with the checks she cashes from her job. When a writer tells a story it is a narrative text. I hope you can both learn something from Anne's mistake! Great job _user_!

Answer.name: IncorrectPrompt
Answer.text: _user_ since we read a passage that describes an experience, or story from Anne herself, that makes this article a what? A narrative, informational, or persuasive text?

Answer.name: BlankPrompt
Answer.text: Give it a shot _user_! Is the article a narrative, persuasive, or informational text?

Answer.name: Assertion
Answer.text: The passage tells us a story of how Anne pays her bills with the checks she cashes from her job. When a writer tells a story it is a narrative text. I hope you can both learn something from Anne's mistake!

Answer.name: AskJordan
Answer.text: What do you think the answer is ComputerStudent1?

Answer.name: JordanAnswer
Answer.text: I think this article is informational because I saw some facts.

Question.text: _user_ since I have to pay a bill like Anne, where could I go to pay my utility bill after I cash my check?

Answer.name: JordanAnswer
Answer.text: I see now _user_! I could go to a money service center in a grocery store to pay my bills, just like Anne.

Question.text: _user_ what could happen if I go to a place that is not authorized to take bill payments? This seems like an important question.

Answer.name: Correct
Answer.text: If ComputerStudent1 goes to a place that is not authorized to take bill payments someone may steal his money. If you aren't sure whether you can pay your bills at a service location, ask the store manager or someone with authority.

Answer.name: IncorrectPrompt

Answer.text: Give it a shot _user_! What could happen if I go to a place that is not authorized to take bill payments?

Answer.name: Assertion
Answer.text: If ComputerStudent1 goes to a place that is not authorized to take bill payments someone may steal his money. If you aren't sure whether you can pay your bills at a service location, ask the store manager or someone with authority.

Answer.name: AskJordan
Answer.text: What do you think the answer is to the question ComputerStudent1?

Answer.name: JordanAnswer
Answer.text: Thanks _user_! I understand now that if a place is not authorized to receive bill payments somebody could trick me into paying them.
